												First, European Ship Simulator was not created by the same development team that brought you Eurotruck Simulator. Arguably, there was an effort by the Euroboat team to make it appear that way. Unfortunately, with European Ship Simulator, what you get is a shallow experience at best without any campaign mode, meaningful objectives, or even a sense of immersion to say the least.  I've completed 4 of the missions so far, successfully I might add, and it wasn't challenging at all. You have a short selection of "Missions" along side a mission editor. I started off with a tug boat mission. The tug boat itself was sufficiently detailed and breaking into open sea from the harbor was satisfying, the choppiness kicked up and there seemed to be correct current physics to deal with. That, unfortunately, was about all there was to be impressed by.   Dropping the tug was a simple press-this-button, which displays a bunch of balloons around your boat. All I had to do was select one of my ballons, and click on the balloon from the ship I would be towing. This easy process connects the two balloons together with a rope, instantly. At this point I'm ready to tow. The massive tanker's front end would dip inappropriately into the sea while towing, which was weird. The physics aren't perfect but I can get passed it. There is no complicated mooring procedure either once you get to your destination. You simply float to the next arrow and you're done. Congratulations. *yawn*  Later, I tried the speedboat. A speedboat mission! My objective was to drive my speedboat to a yacht and pick up a rich lady in distress. On my way, I clipped through just about every bit of ocean, I was practically a submarine. Additionally, the reaction of the boat to the choppy water felt so unauthentic that it made me feel like the developers included this irritation just to force me to press the A and D keys a whole bunch of times and not fall asleep.  To spice things up, I tried the cruise liner. I figured, this should be a challenge. Wrong again, and that brings me to my conclusion. European Ship Simulator is a disaster at the price it is asking. I've played more complex and immersive sims on the iPad. I don't know how some people came the the conclusions they did by recommending this game, it really does make me wonder. The game offers you nothing in return for your effort. It is over-simplified, unrealistic and broken. Wait for the massive content update it needs and in the meantime there are better boating simulators out there.

Early Access Review
								Below you'll find a video and written impression of the game


YouTube™ Video: European Ship Simulator: Early Impressions 

			Views: 1,278		

			European Ship Simulator: Early Impressions European Ship Simulator video created on version: 633 European Ship Simulator is an up coming simulation game of boats, ships, and all sorts of things that...		

European Ship Simulator is exactly as the name states, it is a simulation of what it's like to take control of a variety of European style ships. It's in early access so there is still a ways to go for this game but it does show some promise.Graphically the game looks mostly top-notch. The interior of the ship's cabin are well detailed with high resolution textures and great quality models. You'll find all the small intricacies that you would in a real ship, switches, knobs, GPS, etc, which helps with immersion. The water and weather effects are also some great stuff as well. Though the ship's interior, and the ships them selves show some good quality, the game isn't 100% consistent at the moment. Some of the environmental models, such as buildings, the docks, and streets, are very low polygon and features low resolution textures. I'm hoping that these lacking elements in the visuals are just place holders until a later / final build. Audio wise I got no complaints as the sound effects are realistic with great background noises from the boat's motor and the sounds of the ocean itself keeping you company. As far as gameplay goes, It's surprisingly easy to learn and to get adjusted to, as the main controls is "WASD". Some ships will feature the option of more intricate controls with the num pad, allowing you to manipulate each of the ship's engines individually. Even at it's early stage, the game does a good job at simulating what it's like to drive a ship...for better or worst. I say this because, though the game achieves good results as a simulation, due to what it's simulating it may make it an incompatible for some gamers. Unlike Euro Truck Simulator, where you have the micromanagement of traffic, following traffic laws, avoiding cars, etc, European Ship Simulator is mostly "set sails to full" then auto-pilot straight. There will be lulls where you are simply doing nothing but watching the waves as you wait for your ship to arrive in a straight line to your destination. For enthusiast of simulation games or sailing, this won't be an issue, as that demographic probably already understand this before jumping in, but for the average gamer who is just curious to this game, know that this is a simulation before it's a game.Currently at the time of this impression (version 633), there isn't much in the way of options, graphics, or audio, and there is only 4 missions available with no linking campaign or side features. This is early access I do understand, but at the same time I think it's fair to let people know that in it's current state, it is the bare minimum.Overall, European Ship Simulator shows a lot of promise, that I think will shape up to be some thing quite interesting. But currently, it does feel rather unfinished. If you are a simulation game or ship/boat enthusiast, it might be worth your cash to check it out, even in it's early stages, but for every one else, keep an eye on it, but wait for later versions or even it's final release.Pros:- Mostly realistic and high quality visuals- Feels realistic- Varied amount of ships are enjoyable to cruise around in- Shows promise of a bright futureCons:- Visual quality not 100% consistent- Feels very incomplete currently (ver: 633)- Subject matter might not be as universally appearling as Euro Truck Simulator

												This is a most enjoyable game, but there is some room for improvement. The graphics, especially of bridge interiors, are excellent. While I'm not an expert on ship physics, they seem pretty good. The learning curve for this game is not too steep, by and large, and after a couple of early failures, I have played about 75% of the missions and passed them all. However, the game does have one or two little bugs, and there are some areas where it could improve:1) The text goes weird when you try to change the settings. It's OK initially, but when you go back a screen after making your desired change, it all gets screwed up somehow.2) Ships seem rather too fragile. You can sink by hitting a pier at low speed! The level of damage needs to be more realistically adjusted.3) The AI boats behave strangely at times. In the cruise liner mission for example, a boat that appeared to be going past me suddenly turned in a sharp circle right in front of me! They are also unrealistically indestructible - bump into one, and you'll sink, but it won't!4) In the "berth the ferry in a severe storm" mission, the weather is actually perfectly calm!5) As others have mentioned, there is no career or campaign mode. This would boost the game enormously, as currently there's not a lot left to do after you've played the missions (although you can supposedly make up your own, or edit existing ones, with the Mission Editor).I also think the game could possibly benefit from time being sped up a little à la Euro Truck Simulator, or maybe players could be given the choice between "real" time and "fast" time. Some missions kind of drag a bit, even when you're going at your boat's maximum speed. But these bugs and irritants notwithstanding, the game is generally good fun, which is why I recommend it overall. Also, it is a fairly new product that the developers are giving a lot of time to right now. Already since I bought it, there has been an update. So hopefully this promising game will soon be even better in the future.

												An excellent ship simulator (if that is what you are into).  However, the game could have been so much more, but a dispute during development spoiled all that.  I had no trouble installing or playing the game.  I have decent frame rates on the highest settings and have not had a crash as of yet.Pros:  The graphics are very good and easily on par with FSX and are more like Silent Service 5.  The bridges are very nicely done indeed and remind me of some of the addon planes cockpits that I have for FSX.  Highly detailed, large in some cases and very nicely executed.  The exterior orbit camera mode is very nice too and the ships look very good.  I am not a sailor, but the player ships do seem to move very well and are not overly responsive.  There are even seaguls flying around the ports.Cons:  No freeroam mode with missions only.  There are not a lot of missions either, but there is step by step guide on the Steam Forum to teach you how to create your own missions.  I could not find any downloadable missions, addons or mods on the internet.  You are locked into the bridge and cannot wander about the ships (fair enough - you are stuck in the cockpit in FSX as well).  There is no career mode or campaign.  The water within the ports should be far calmer than the outside sea.  That is the whole point of the water break haven walls!  The water break on the bows of the ships is static and stays in place even when the bow is lifting up out of the sea on the crest of a wave.  It does not move with the level of the sea.  There are no other crew members or people to be seen, nor is there any radio traffic, so it is a bit lonely and quiet.  There is no full world out there (hence no free roam), just some routes built in to enable travel to and from specific ports only.  The other AI ships have a ridiculously amazing ability to turn on the spot at speed.  Not very realistic to watch a large container carrier turning on a sixpence like a jet-ski.  There are far too many controls, buttons and screens in the bridge which do not work and are not interactive.  Lastly, the Time Jump button is only active for a short time.  If you do not use it in time, you will have to do the entire voyage in real time!Conclusion:  This game by graphics is streets ahead of it's intended successor 'World Ship Simulator' which looks very childish and rudimentary by comparison to this game.  The fact is, this game could have been so much more.  The day will come when someone finally makes a ship simulator along the lines of FSX and X-Plane.  This game could have a full world out there, with more controls working in the bridge.  It could have been done in such a way that other developers get involved with building addon ports, ships with fully working bridges, interactive port communications as per FSX, etc and giving some of the take to this games developers.  Just as we have with FSX.  A missed opportunity there.  I have Ship Simulator 2008 which is let down by it's old graphics and I also have the early access 'World Ship Simulator'.  So far, European Ship Simulator knocks the socks of those in terms of beauty and bridge detail.  For it's current price of £5 ($7.50) on sale at time of writing, it is well worth a look.

												(please note that I decided to write this review is interspersed with comparisons between this Ship Simulator and the older Ship Simulator by Vstep)Bit of a mixed bag this one, frankly not very impressed with it, espesially given that I myself am a sailor (though by no means a captain) with a little boat handling experience.When compared to Vstep's long abandoned Ship Simulator series this one's got quite a lot of catching up to do, even though the Vstep shipsim has numerous faults of it's own.First thing I noticed about this game that kind of set the trend for what I was expecting of it was the poor terminology used in the manual, for example referencing to the 'Front Engine' and 'Rear Engine Throttle' controls, the proper names for these being the Bow and Stern Thrusters.As far as I can tell this game has only two features better than that of the Vstep shipsim. The first being the inclusion of independent control for port and starboard azimuth steering units, as found on the Tug, though unfortunely let down by the clear fact this game's developers obviously don't know exacly how these units work in real life. The second, possibly more obvious one, being the distinct lack of bugs which were a notorious problem with the Vstep simulator. As far as thing go thats about it for being ahead of it's (dormant) competition.Where graphics are concerned this game isn't too bad, all things considered, it's fairly level with the Vstep one, though I would consider Vstep to be slightly ahead. So far I can't say I've found much in the way of issues with the physics, but I may be wrong. However there are a few things with the physics and general effects that could do with attention, such as for some reason the ships seem to create a bow wave when going astern (reversing), and one thing I found when I came along side the cargo ship in the first tug mission, I lightly brushed the side of the ship with the side of the tug, a move that would be fairly common place in reality, resulted in severe damage and caused me to sink. In reality the tug would be fitted with rubber fenders, as can actually be seen on it's sides in the game, which are there to dampen any very light brushes resulting in minimal damage, if any.This game has a little more in the way of interactive/functional controls on the bridge, though frankly their functions being fairly unrealistic, such as light and horn switches. The horn seems to operate on a repeating pulse setting when turned on and won't stop until turned off again. Personally I think they missed a trick here as they could have opted for a selective horn signalling system as used on real ships, one-uping Vstep. The lighting is something they really put no though into as it only turns on a few deck lights, not the more obvious navigation lights.The steering isn't that great, though thankfully is much better than the horrible control setup of Ship Simulator:  Maritime Search and Rescue. One rather nice touch with the controls is that both the throttle and steering are set so that they take time to complete their movments, as in real life, rather than just instand full rudder or power. The steering/rudder angle on the featured ships only goes up to 10 degrees in either direction, both poor and unrealistic as the typical maximum rudder angle for the average ship is 40-45 degrees, as reflected in the Vstep game. As I mentioned before, the developers of this game decided to include the use of azimuth steering units with certain vessels, as did Vstep, but unlike Vstep did have enough of a brainwave to program in individual steering control, but unfortunately They don't actually know how these units work, where as Vstep do. Just to clear up, an azimuth unit is effectively a pod fitted with a propeller mounted under the ship which can be rotated though 360 degrees thus eliminating the need for a rudder or reverse gear and giving the ship better agility than with a conventional rudder and fixed-shaft propeller setup.Just like the Vstep shipsim, this on comes with a mission editor. At first it seems quite simple to use but I still haven't got the hang of it, so I suspect looks may be deceiving, also not really helped by the camera being in a fixed birds-eye-view, only the height above ground being ajustable. Good luck to anyone who can figure it out.To sum it all up this game does have potential here, but I'm not convinced by it. The best thing the developers of this game could do is have a good long shot with Vsteps (now possibly abandoned or furgotten, jugging by their website) Ship Simulator series and see where this game has to improve. So I don't recommend this game, at least not yet.Instead I recommend you try out one of the Ship Simulator series from Vstep, The newest one Ship Simulator Extremes (2009 release) being available on Steam, but be prepared for bugs/glitches which are likely to appear.

												At the current state, I can recommend this game only for die-hard ship simulator fans. For these people, it'll probably be like heaven. At first. Currently there are only a few missions to play but since this is an Early Access-game, it's totally understandable. Some missions have a time limit, if you exceed it by 1 second, it doesn't matter if you played for like.. 2 hours. Mission failed, that's all, plus an immediate return to the homescreen. The graphics are still quite buggy and unoptimized. But hey, it's Early Access. What really annoys me though is that the developer seems to focus on new content, not on bug fixes. And of course, it takes a loooot of time to create new content. Meanwhile you have a buggy game with a couple of missions, and perhaps every month a new mission. That is what I see here right now. CTDs are quite common, happens to me 70% of tries to play a mission, it crashes within the first 10 seconds. What I fear is that the game might become like the other ship simulators. Buggy, repetitive games with minimal content in terms of different things to do on the vessel.Also, there are only the Steam Forums to communicate with the developer and well, I haven't seen him responding to any recommendations whatsoever on what to change in the game.I think it is great that there's finally someone who wants to bring a new ship simulator to the market, but at the moment, I cannot recommend the average player to buy it, especially at this price. Wait a couple of months until major enhancements have (hopefully) been made so that you can see in which direction the game goes: the old Ship Simulator games or something new and really different.// Update: 13.02.2015 - I was quite astonished when the developer announced that the game will leave early access next week, which means that it'll be on steam as an officially finished game. Although the developer said that they'll "continue to work" on it, I do not think that this is a good way for a game. It still has minimalistic content and is very unoptimized, containing disastrous bugs such as the horizon which is full of weird blue lines, flickering around and destroying the game's atmosphere. They have not been able to fix these for months. And how can you say that the game is finished when even the menus of some indie games made on unity look better than this one?

								It's an ok start, but too early for being on sale. Criminally unstable and buggy, and I say that not because I don't expect an alpha game to be buggy, but it often makes to where 5% of my mission attempts actually let me finish a mission without crashing or locking up. There is also no save function(manual or automatic, so you will lose your progress.)There is also effectively no settings menu. Low, Medium, and High and none of them seem to affect how the game looks. No vsync, reflections, distance, AA, nothing. The game certainly looks pretty, water reflections and physics are nice. Sitting inside the tug boat out in the ocean feels very realistic, however the actual buildings and cities a long the coast look like something from HotWheels Crash. It performs really well on my system, but that's something I'd expect, again looks nice, but not amazing. The game has nice sounds, the roar of the engines below and the horn on the ships all sound fitting, though that's mostly all you'll hear. That and seagulls for hours because the skip time function will probably break for you as well. Like I started with, it's a decent start, but under no circumstances would I suggest a casual player to purchase this. Only someone who is a big fan of ships and ocean simulators. Even then, they will probably go through all the content very quickly.Launching February 2015 seems pretty soon, wait for launch before taking the dive off the starboard.

Early Access Review
								Changing my position since the Early Access Review (read below). This simulator is still bare bones, and lots of bugs. It would be really fine if it was still under Early Access, but sadly it is not anymore. This is not the final product I was expecting. Here's an example, starting my tug mission at somewhat 13:00 hours, it should be bright outside. But it feels like dusk. The brightness and daylight is wrong. I start moving my tug to two ships that collided a few miles from my position. The movement of the ship in the water feels superficial, as there is no proper wake and although the bow wake seems fine, it still needs work. The water displacement, which you would expect from a couple of tons ship is barely noticeable. There is also water transparency missing.  A few other simulator and games have done a better job at wake too, like Total War: Rome 2, Deadliest Catch: Alaskan Storm, Silent Hunter Series, and even Spintires(The best water simulation and wake I've seen in a while).Moving forward...There is no depth radar, and only basic instrumentation. Reaching the two ships I receive the order to attach my tug boat to one of them. Sure, the line attached to my boat is also bugged, as in it doesn't look tied but like a big gigantic straight piece of rope glued to the ship. Moving on, a few minutes later a Coast Guard ship collides with the ship being towed. Showed no desire to slow down or deviate from the collision. In fact, it kept going even when it still collided to my towed ship. A few minutes later, my ship and the towed ship jumps around and I'm suddenly sinking! I hope the devs doesn't get dishearten over their product, because there are still a lot of love in it. Which I explained in my Early Access review. Like the texturing of the ships, the lights, and the water. But this is definitely not a finished product and I sadly CAN NOT recommend it as such. As an Early Access, sure, but not the way it is now. Buy it when it is on sale or when they fix this (which I will update this review accordingly if there are changes and if those changes are positive, I will recommend the simulator at a later stage)__________________________________________________________EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:So far, the simulator seems to be scratching an itch that hasn't been scratched in ages. I love the attention to detail, and how they really bothered in making the ships. I love ferries but I fell in love with the fishing ship. Life huh! I also love the water, although I feel it needs a bit more love as in transparency (side of boats and docks and depth) refraction and reflection. But I would also love if we had proper ship wakes. A few games that managed to nail wakes, that I've seen are Silent Hunter 3/4/5, Deadliest Catch: Alaskan Storm(dynamic wakes) and Spintires(Dynamic wakes), and I would love to see that beautifully well-formed foam around the ship, giving a sense of movement, or that you are displacing tons of water.And the developer's approach to the community and how they are handling criticism, suggestion and even the comments are very commendable. I think this simulator has shown a lot of promise, and I can't wait to see the developer’s dreams over this simulator come true. I also like how the light reflects over the surface of the ship, tiny things like that immerses you more than you can imagine. In other words, it is still Early Access, bare bones, probably pre-alpha, and still needs a lot of work, but what it already has is fun and worth the money! So, if you like simulation and ships, this is definitely something you should buy!

Early Access Review
								Changing my position since the Early Access Review (read below). This simulator is still bare bones, and lots of bugs. It would be really fine if it was still under Early Access, but sadly it is not anymore. This is not the final product I was expecting. Here's an example, starting my tug mission at somewhat 13:00 hours, it should be bright outside. But it feels like dusk. The brightness and daylight is wrong. I start moving my tug to two ships that collided a few miles from my position. The movement of the ship in the water feels superficial, as there is no proper wake and although the bow wake seems fine, it still needs work. The water displacement, which you would expect from a couple of tons ship is barely noticeable. There is also water transparency missing.  A few other simulator and games have done a better job at wake too, like Total War: Rome 2, Deadliest Catch: Alaskan Storm, Silent Hunter Series, and even Spintires(The best water simulation and wake I've seen in a while).Moving forward...There is no depth radar, and only basic instrumentation. Reaching the two ships I receive the order to attach my tug boat to one of them. Sure, the line attached to my boat is also bugged, as in it doesn't look tied but like a big gigantic straight piece of rope glued to the ship. Moving on, a few minutes later a Coast Guard ship collides with the ship being towed. Showed no desire to slow down or deviate from the collision. In fact, it kept going even when it still collided to my towed ship. A few minutes later, my ship and the towed ship jumps around and I'm suddenly sinking! I hope the devs doesn't get dishearten over their product, because there are still a lot of love in it. Which I explained in my Early Access review. Like the texturing of the ships, the lights, and the water. But this is definitely not a finished product and I sadly CAN NOT recommend it as such. As an Early Access, sure, but not the way it is now. Buy it when it is on sale or when they fix this (which I will update this review accordingly if there are changes and if those changes are positive, I will recommend the simulator at a later stage)__________________________________________________________EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:So far, the simulator seems to be scratching an itch that hasn't been scratched in ages. I love the attention to detail, and how they really bothered in making the ships. I love ferries but I fell in love with the fishing ship. Life huh! I also love the water, although I feel it needs a bit more love as in transparency (side of boats and docks and depth) refraction and reflection. But I would also love if we had proper ship wakes. A few games that managed to nail wakes, that I've seen are Silent Hunter 3/4/5, Deadliest Catch: Alaskan Storm(dynamic wakes) and Spintires(Dynamic wakes), and I would love to see that beautifully well-formed foam around the ship, giving a sense of movement, or that you are displacing tons of water.And the developer's approach to the community and how they are handling criticism, suggestion and even the comments are very commendable. I think this simulator has shown a lot of promise, and I can't wait to see the developer’s dreams over this simulator come true. I also like how the light reflects over the surface of the ship, tiny things like that immerses you more than you can imagine. In other words, it is still Early Access, bare bones, probably pre-alpha, and still needs a lot of work, but what it already has is fun and worth the money! So, if you like simulation and ships, this is definitely something you should buy!

												Many have slagged this game off for being "too slow" or lacking gameplay, some say it is boring. I have helmed ships big and small in real life and have to say that the reactions to engine and helm are spot on. This is the best shipping simulator I have been on. Graphics are brilliant, plenty of single player missions and the ability to build your own missions as well. The 3d enviroment within the bridge of each ship is stunning, and controls whilst simplistic, are sufficient for anyone. The introductory mission of tug and tow, is quite accurate, and the final "nesting" of the  cargo freighter into its assigned berth is testing but fun using both towing skills, knowing when to drop the tow, and final pushing along the hull to adjust freighters position. In real terms, these jobs on full size vessels must be done slowly and with care to avoid accident or damage, this is reflected in what you do here. For a fun game simulator, I was a bit dubious about purchasing at firest, but now I am glad that I got it.
